text: We have noticed that, as the independent variable changes by a constant amount, there is a constant pattern of change in the dependent variable. In the last Problem, the graph representing Alana’s pledge plan crossed the y-axis at point at (0, 5). Leanne’s crosses the y-axis at point at (0, 10). Gilberto’s pledge plan crossed the y-axis at (0, 0). These points are called the y-intercepts. The y-intercept is the point where the line crosses the y-axis, or when x = 0.
In this Problem we will continue to explore linear relationships in new contexts.
What information does the y-intercept represent?
How might it be useful in solving problems?
